document.docAuthor: Burke, Alan F., Leavengood, John M., Scholtz, Clarke H. & Sole, Catherine L.
document.masterDocTitle: Redescription of the holotype of Bostrichoclerus bicornus Van Dyke, 1938, a rare species of the New World Tillinae Fauna (Coleoptera: Cleridae), with some taxonomic notes

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Redescription of the holotype of Bostrichoclerus bicornus Van Dyke, 1938, a rare species of the New World Tillinae Fauna (Coleoptera: Cleridae), with some taxonomic notes

bibRefCitation.author: Van Dyke, E. C.
bibRefCitation.refString: Van Dyke, E. C. (1938) New species of Pacific Coast Coleoptera (Cleridae, Pyrochroidae, Chrysomelidae). Entomological News, 49, 189 - 195.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type species.
Bostrichoclerus bicornus Van Dyke, 1938
, original designation (monotypy).

Type locality.
Palm Cañon, Angel de la Guardia , Golf of California , Mexico
.
Type depository: California Academy of Sciences ( CASC )
.

materialsCitation.collectorName: Angel de la Guardia Isd & Palm Cn. & Gulf Calif. & J. C. Chamberlin Collector

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype , a female, red labelled ( Fig. 19 ): Angel de la Guardia Isd , Palm Cn. , Gulf Calif. ,
May-3-1921
, J.C. Chamberlin Collector , apparently near genus
Natalis
, California Academy of Sciences Entomology Type no. 4682. Abdomen attached to a cardboard piece ( Figs 8 , 19 ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Differential diagnosis: The structure of the antennae ( Fig. 4 ) as well as the bisinuate lateral margin of the pronotum ( Fig. 1 ) of
B. bicornus
resemble members of the speciose genus
Cymatodera
. The former species is easily recognized from
Cymatodera
and other Tillinae species based on the prominent frontal horns ( Figs 2, 3, 5 ) and the elytral disc lacking clear rows of striae ( Fig. 1 ). This combination of characters is not found in any other Tillinae species. In addition to the frontal horns and the absence of clear rows of striae,
B. bicornus
has simple tarsal claws ( Figs 12-13 ). With the exception of
Onychotillus Chapin
, where simple tarsal claws are also seen, remaining genera of New World Tillinae have the tarsal claws with two denticles.

Description: Holotype female. TL = 22.57 mm. Form elongate, slightly robust; metathoracic wings fully developed. Color: Head, pronotum, elytra, antennae and legs piceous; mouthparts, prosternum, mesoventrite and metaventrite dark ferrugineous; serrate portion of antennomeres 6–11 more testaceous due to patches of sensillae; elytral surface without any markings or bands ( Figs 1, 4 , 10 ).

with metacoxae removed, 9. Abdomen of

FIGURES 10–13. 10. Mouthparts of the holotype of
B. bicornus

B. bicornus
collected in southern California, 15. Close-up of the frons in dorsal view, 16. Close-up of the frons in lateral view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality:
The type material was collected at a single locality in Palm Canyon, Angel de la Guarda Island. This is a semiarid island part of the Mexican state of Baja California. According to the original description of Van Dyke (1938) , the specimen was captured beneath the bark of an unknown plant species.
